description.narrative: HPF3 merges two previous health programmes; Health Pooled Fund 2 (HPF2), which provides health care at health facility level, and the Integrated Community Case Management 2 (ICCM2) programme, which provides health care to children under-five within more remote communities. HPF3 is programmed between 2018 and 2023 (5 years). HPF3 supports delivery of essential primary health care in the community and through a network of health care facilities, secondary health care and referral health services. In addition it supports the stabilisation of local health systems and the strengthening of community ownership and governance structures. Finally HPF3 is responsible for the procurement and supply chain management of essential medical commodities. A break point of HPF3 is planned for in 2021 to provide an opportunity to either change the direction or the scale of the programme if this is deemed necessary. The HPF3 sees two options at this break point: the situation in South Sudan has changed dramatically and the conditions for sustainable health system development appear favourable, then funding might not be needed. However this scenario is considered unlikely. More likely is that donors would be more willing to support a World Bank led-trust fund model with greater government ownership. HPF3 supports services in eight out of ten hubs of South Sudan in the states formerly known as: Central Equatoria, Eastern Equatoria, Lakes, Northern Bahr el Ghazal, Unity, Warrap, Western Bahr el Ghazal and Western Equatoria. The two remaining former states, Jonglei and Upper Nile, will be funded by a World Bank funded programme and implemented by ICRC and UNICEF as contracted partners. The overall HPF3 programme impact will be an improved health and nutrition status for the population that saves lives and reduces morbidity (including maternal, infant and under-5 mortality), and has the following three principal outcomes: -Improved health and nutrition services for the population, especially women and children. -Improved community engagement and accountability of health services. -Stabilisation of local health systems. The recipients of services are primarily the state run health services in South Sudan. The direct beneficiaries are the South Sudanese people, with particular focus on mothers, pregnant women and children under five years of age. HPF3 will contribute to three of the UN Sustainable Development goals as well as the global programme Scale up Nutrition and the global partnership to empower women and girls by investing in rights-based family planning; FP 2020.

Insatsen omfattar stöd med totalt 300 MSEK till den tredje fasen av Health Pooled Fund (HPF3) under åren 2019-2021. Sida har tidigare bidragit till fondens fas 1 och fas 2 under åren 2012-2018 med totalt 299 MSEK. Stödet för HPF3 är en ökning i aktivitetsperiod samt beloppsvolym vilket finner sin förklaring i de stora medelsbehoven inom fonden direkt kopplat till de stora behoven av hälsoservice i Sydsudan. Sida bedömer det möjligt att bidra till dessa behov genom dels en längre aktivitetsperiod samt en ökad finansieringen, jämfört med Sidas tidigare stöd till HPF. Utrymme för detta ges iom den förlängda strategiperioden (5 år) samt det ökade anslaget som beslutats om inom ramen för strategin för Sveriges utvecklingssamarbete med Sydsudan 2018-2022. Under första årets budget av HPF3 kommer Sidas uppgå till 13% men andelen kan minskas om EU beslutar sig för att bidra till HPF3. Under 2021 kommer DFID att utvärdera programmet. Utvärderingen skall vägleda ett beslut huruvida programmet skall forsätta i samma konstellation programperioden ut eller alternativt söka en sammanslagning med Världsbankens program som implementeras i de två delstater där HPF3 inte är verksamt. Bereonde på utkomsten kommer Sida avseende eventuellt framtida stöd att bedöma behovet om eventuell förlänging av aktivitesperioden och medelstillskjutning till det forsatta programmet alternativt stödja det nya programmet.
HPF utformades 2012 som en givargemensam fond som leds av DFID och där andra givare till fonden i nuläget är Sverige, Kanada och USA. HPF3´s program är utformat i enlighet med antagna nationella hälsopolicies, framför allt "BasicPackage for Health and Nutrition Services", "Health Sector Development Plan" och "Health Sector Strategic Plan".
DFID har i enlighet med EUs upphandlingregler, upphandlat en fondförvaltare för HPF3. Fondförvaltaren för HPF3 är Crown Agents. Crown Agents är ett internationellt privat icke-vinstdrivande företag som arbetar i utvecklingsländer med att bla stärkande av hälso- och utbildningssystem samt inom humanitära sektorn. Crown Agents arbetar i över 100 länder och kunderna är framför allt multinationella företag, regeringar, FN och biståndsgivare såsom EU, DFID, Världsbanken och Kanada.
Inom HPF3 är Crown Agents ansvarig för genomförandet av HPF3 under ledning av DFID. Crown Agents i sin tur leder ett konsortium som består av ytterligare tre (3) eniteter som bidrar med sin expertiskunskap inom bl.a. områden som upphandling, forskning relaterat till HPF3 programmet och logistik.
Crown Agents kallar till givarmöten för HPF3 månadsvis. Vid dessa möten redogörs för programmets utgifter och en reviderad budget presenteras. Utöver budgetfrågan tas andra aktuella frågor upp löpande och givarna har möjlighet att förslå agendapunkter samt göra inspel till agendapunkterna. HPF3 har även en styrkommitté som håller möten 4 gånger om året. Styrkommittén leds av representant från hälsoministeriet, vanligtvis statssekreteraren, tillsammans med DFID. Alla givare är representerade, samt personal från hälsoministeriet och fondförvaltaren. För HPF3 har medlemmar tillkommit med representanter från Världsbankens hälsoprogram, som implementeras i de två delstater där HPF3 inte är närvarande, och Världbanksprogrammets implementerande partner, detta i syfte att stärka samordningen mellan de båda programmen. Medlemmarna i styrkommittéens främsta uppgift är att vägleda och bidra i strategiska programbeslut, att bidra till en stärkt samordning inom hälsosektorn och att försäkra att HPF3 programmet är i linje med de nationella hälsopolicies som programmet vilar på. Sida bedömer sin medverkan i styrkommittén av betydelse för insyn och möjlighet att påverka och vägleda strategiska beslut i den rikting som Sida vill se att programmet utformas och utvecklas åt.
Crown Agents upphandlar implementerande partner för genomförandet av aktiviteter. I HPF3 har 13 st implementerande partner upphandlats som täcker 21 geografiskt uppdelade områden. Dessa implementerande partner består av internationella och nationella icke-statliga organsiationer (NGOs). De implementerade partnerna skriver under Terms of Reference där uppdraget tydligt defineras. Alla aktiviteter utövas inom ramen för det nationella hälsosystemets strukturer och organisation och med hjälp av personal anställd av hälsoministeriet. De implementerande partnerna betalar en bonus till ett definerat antal personal som krävs för att utföra uppdraget. Denna bonus är utöver den lön som hälsoministeriets ansvar för att betala månadsvis, men som i praktiken utbetalas väldigt oregelbundet och dessutom utgör en väldigt låg summa. Inga medel inom HPF3 överförs direkt till hälsoministeriet eller andra myndigheter.
HPF3 stödjer grundläggande hälso- och sjukvårdsservice i Sydsudan genom ett nätverk av sjukvårdsinrättningar på framför allt primär men i viss omfattning även sekundär nivå. I tillägg främjar programmet stabiliseringen av det nationella hälso- och sjukvårdssystemet och stärkandet av samhällsägarskap och styrningsstrukturer. Slutligen är Crown Agents ansvarig för upphandling och logistikkedjan av viktiga medicinska produkter så som läkemedel och medicinskt material och utrustning.
På sikt kommer effekten av HPF3 att bli en förbättrad hälso- och näringsstatus hos befolkningen som sparar liv och minskar sjukligheten (inklusive mödra-, spädbarns- och under-5-års dödlighet) och har följande tre huvudresultat:
- Ökat och förbättrat utbud av hälso- och nutritionsservice för Sydsudans befolkning, med särskilt fokus på kvinnor och barn. - Ökat samhällsengagemang och ansvarstagande för hälsovårdstjänster. - Stabilisering av det nationella hälsosystemet.
Mottagare av tjänsterna är främst den statliga sjukvården i Sydsudan. De direkta mottagarna är Sydsudaneser med särskild inriktning på mödrar, gravida kvinnor och barn under fem år.
Sida bedömmer att HPF3 tar i beaktande fattiga människors perspektiv då ett av målen med progammet är att adressera extrem fattigdom. HPF3 integrerar principen om icke-diskriminering då de tjänster som erbjuds finns tillgängliga för hela populationen inom de geografiska områden där HPF3 implementeras. Ett nytillkommet fokus inom HPF3 är att utforma programmet att anpassas till de särskilda behov som finns hos människor med funktionsnedsättning och som söker programmets tjänster. Sida bedömer att HPF3 har ett integrerat jämställdhetsperspektiv med flera mätbara mål. HPF3 har avsatt personal enbart för att arbeta med att stödja, följa upp, och utvärdera implementerande partners kapacitet att integrera jämställdhet genom hela programcykel. Sida anser dock att detta arbete kan förbättras ytterligare och kommer driva frågan om en förnyad och fördjupad jämställhetsanalys för att säkerställa att programmet adresserar de brister som identifierats i analysen.
Genomförandet av HPF3 sker i nära samarbete med de av Crown Agents upphandlade implementerande samarbetspartner (NGOs) samt med myndigheter på decentraliserad nivå. På grund av tidigare år av rådande konflikt samt den sydsudanesiska statens begränsade kapacitet och resurser har det initiala fokuset för programmet skiftat från hälsosystemstärkande ansats som att bygga system för upphandling och distribution av läkemedel, personal och finansiella system, till ett större fokus på genomförande av hälsotjänster, delvis i humanitär form där situationen kräver så. Trots stora utmaningar och tack vare ett flexibelt upplägg har HPF under fas 1 och 2 uppvisat goda resultat.

Sida´s support to the Health Pooled Fund 3 (HPF3) in South Sudan amounts to SEK 300 million over a period of 3 years (2019-2021) including provision of health services to 8 out of 10 former states in South Sudan. Sida has previously contributed to the fund's Phase 1 and Phase 2 during the years 2012-2018 amounting a total of SEK 299 million.
The fund was designed in 2012 as a multi-donor fund managed by DFID and with presently includes Sweden, Canada and the US.
HPF3 supports delivery of essential primary health care in the community and through a network of health care facilities, secondary health care and referral health services. In addition it supports the stabilisation of local health systems and the strengthening of community ownership and governance structures. Finally HPF3 is responsible for the procurement and supply chain management of essential medical commodities.
HPF3 programme impact will be an improved health and nutrition status for the population that saves lives and reduces morbidity (including maternal, infant and under-5 mortality), and has the following three principal outcomes:
- Improved health and nutrition services for the population, especially women and children. - Improved community engagement and accountability of health services. - Stabilisation of local health systems.
The recipients of services are primarily the state run health services in South Sudan. The direct beneficiaries are the South Sudanese people, with particular focus on mothers, pregnant women and children under five years of age.
Sida believes that HPF3 takes into account the poor peoples´ perspective as one of the objectives of the program is to address extreme poverty. HPF3 integrates the principle of non-discrimination as the services offered are available to the entire population in the geographical areas where HPF3 is implemented. A new focus within HPF3 is to design the program to be adapted to the specific needs of people living with disabilities and who are utilising the program's services. Sida believes that HPF3 has an integrated gender equality perspective with several measurable goals. HPF3 has dedicated staff only to work to support, monitor, and evaluate implementing partners' capacity to integrate gender equality throughout the program cycle. However, Sida believes that this work can be further improved and will work for the programm to undertake a renewed and in-depth gender equality analysis to ensure that the program addresses the shortcomings identified in the analysis.
The implementation takes place in close collaboration with civil society organizations and health authorities at a decentralized level. Due to previous years of prevailing conflict and the limited capacity and resources of the South Sudanese government, the initial focus of the programme has shifted from health system strengthening approaches such as building systems for procurement and distribution of drugs, personnel and financial systems, to the implementation of health services, partly due to a flexible approach and according to humanitarian principles required by the situation. Despite major challenges and due to a flexible programme approach, the HPF has shown good results both in phase 1 and 2.

description.narrative: These below examples of results achieves is based on results presented in the annual report of HPF3 which covers for the first program year of April 2019 to March 2020: The programme has made good progress in the areas of reproductive, maternal, neonatal and child health. The Boma Health Initiative (community health programme) has commenced in the supported areas, a key part of HPF3’s success. The programme has successfully delivered three consignments of essential medicines in all eight states. Health systems have improved notably in the areas of information systems and supervision. HPF3 made progress in the areas of gender equity, disability and social inclusion. Two operational research projects were completed. HPF3 prioritised establishing strong safeguarding policies and reporting mechanisms as part of the fund management responsibilities. The overall risk rating according to our assessments was major. Quality health service delivery HPF3 focuses on core services covering reproductive, maternal, neonatal and child health, including immunisation, nutrition and family planning (FP) services. The project has seen good progress on deliveries in a health facility by a skilled birth attendant (61,509 deliveries, an increase of 10% compared with the same period in 2018) – a critical part of reducing maternal mortality. The 25 hospitals delivered around half of those births. Resuscitation of new-borns and women receiving post-abortion care are both on an upward trend. Key to improvements has been intensified supportive supervisions, on-the-job training, regular monitoring visits, and availability of skilled birth attendants and essential medicines. Of the 794 supported health facilities: 53% are providing family planning counselling services; Couple years protection has shown good progress, surpassing the annual target (achieving 39,127); and The number of new adopters of modern family planning methods has increased by 48,771. Vital childhood immunisation is also improving, with HPF3’s support providing three doses of pentavalent vaccinations to 211,171 children. The most recent estimates of wasting among children aged under five years shows a worsening status in this reporting year. HPF3 has been working to address this through screening and growth monitoring, nutrition awareness raising and referrals through the BHI. A combination of several factors led to a lower number of outpatient visits than was projected. Industrial action taken by health facility staff across most counties as a result of the roll out of the harmonised incentive scale caused disruption of services between April and June 2019 and an unusually long and heavy rainy season caused floods that resulted in poor access to health facilities. However, HPF3 still supported over 6.1 million outpatient consultations (out of a target of 6.5 million). Providing nutrition services has been challenging due to the need to manage children’s general health, lack of child health reporting and lack of tracing of children over time. Community-level interventions The BHI has been a significant change from HPF2 to HPF3, as HPF3 incorporates community health service delivery, extending the continuum of care beyond the health facility. The BHI is more diverse in services than DFID’s previous community health intervention – the Integrated Community Case Management (ICCM) programme. Although targets for treating children have not been met, this is the first time the programme has taken services to communities and individual households at scale, which was not done during previous HPF phases. This has involved the development of a whole new system. Rolling out services across all eight states should be completed around mid-2020. Ensuring access to essential medicines and supplies HPF3 has continued to drive the availability of safe, effective and quality essential medicines throughout the eight states, without which the health system may collapse. HPF3 leads procurement and distribution of essential medicines, with a greater focus this year on last-mile delivery. Key targets have been surpassed, including the number of health facilities receiving commodities within a defined time period from consignment numbers 8, 9 and 10 (84% of facilities); and health facilities with complete commodity consumption reports (87% of facilities), which are critical for forecasting. Since October 2019, HPF3 has monitored if health facilities have any expired drugs (38% of facilities) to drive more effective use of supplies. Unfortunately, the proportion of health facilities that had all tracer medicines available in the past three months was low (19% of facilities). Supporting a stable health system Health committees have been established in 678 of the 794 supported health facilities; 28% of health committees are led by a female chair or co-chair. Completeness of the health facility-level reporting has remained high through the District Health Information System 2 (DHIS2) (98% of facilities). For community DHIS2 reporting, during the first year of the BHI, completeness was 54%, which is commendable considering it is a relatively new reporting system compared to the facility-level reporting. Supportive supervision of facilities remained high, at 75% coverage of facilities. Quality of care (QoC) assessments have also been a feature of HPF3; a high number of facility assessments were completed (73% of facilities), surpassing the target. Where quality improvement plans were developed because of the QoC assessments, the evidence shows that the QoC score improved. HPF3 also supported the government with the Human Resource Information System, solving health workforce industrial action and providing policy support. Cross-cutting areas HPF3 training for gender equity and social inclusion has been rolled out to health workers in 60% of facilities. HPF3 has also trained health workers at 26% of facilities on managing patients with mental health disorders. Knowing that sexual and gender-based violence is a major issue in South Sudan, HPF3 provided training to health workers from 39% of facilities. Across the health facilities, a total of 14,014 people with disabilities were identified during curative consultations. Although HPF3 has some way to go to make a big difference on these difficult and marginalised issues, the activities established a foundation to build on over the next year and will have impact over the duration of HPF3. The HPF consortium completed two studies as part of the operational research mandate: one on barriers and facilitators to community health interventions; and the other on data quality and utilisation of primary care services in South Sudan. During the reporting period, the overall risk assessment was major/substantial. The overall risks were minor in only one county (Budi), moderate in 20 counties and substantial in 33 counties HPF3’s support to government systems will help sustainability beyond the project timeframe. HPF3 and the IPs have been working with government at all levels over the year County Health Departments (CHDs), state MoH and national MoH. HPF3 has supported the government District Health Information System 2 (DHIS2) implementation, the government led BHI, improved human resource planning and human resource information systems usage, supported the development of, and circulated, regulations, policies and organisational structures, and coordinated monthly drug management committee meetings. In addition to the above a key win for HPF3 in Year 1 was the agreement and roll out of the harmonised incentive scale which sought to calibrate discrepancies in incentives between different cadre of health workers.
